text: I'm getting stuck in that there.
That's going to be my blooper? All right.
Hi, I'm Tiona Zuzul.

I'm an assistant professor
in the Strategy Unit
at Harvard Business School.
I study how leaders and managers
think and make decisions
in highly uncertain settings

where the future is unknown
or unpredictable.

And I develop a cognitive perspective
on business strategy in these settings.
So, I show that
the way that leaders interpret

and frame the environment,
their organizations,

and then even their own roles
as leaders
can actually shape business
strategy, firm flexibility or inertia,
and even ultimately firm performance.

When I came to HBS for the first time
as a doctoral student,
I became deeply fascinated
by the insight that different

people can look at the exact same data
and then frame it or interpret
it in completely different ways
that lead to distinct choices.
I'm also a field researcher.
I immerse myself deeply in the industries

and organizations
that I study in order to understand

how the people who shape them
see the world.
I have studied everything from FBI
agents to psychedelic therapy advocates

in order to try to learn from their
insights and experiences.
To lead effective organizations

leaders and managers
have to constantly adapt and innovate.

I hope that by studying leaders
and managers who have done that
in some cases really successfully, in

other cases really unsuccessfully,
I can help prepare the future leaders

of tomorrow for the uncertainty
that is sure to come.
I brought a drawing

that one of my daughters made
when she was two years old.

I think this is actually
her first representational drawing.

And she described it as “me
and my mom under a heart
and a rainbow because we love each other.”
I keep this pinned above my desk
right next to my computer as a daily
reminder of what's really important.
And also the hearts and rainbows.
